fact: The first computer programmer was Ada Lovelace, who wrote an algorithm for Charles Babbage's Analytical Engine in the 1840s.
Python was named after 'Monty Python's Flying Circus,' not the snake.
The first-ever computer bug was an actual moth found in a relay of the Harvard Mark II computer in 1947.
The 'Hello, World!' program was first used in the book 'The C Programming Language' by Brian Kernighan and Dennis Ritchie.
Java was originally called 'Oak' but was renamed because 'Oak' was already trademarked.
Git, the version control system, was created by Linus Torvalds in 2005 to help manage Linux kernel development.
HTML is not a programming language but a markup language used to structure web pages.
The name 'JavaScript' was chosen to ride on the popularity of Java, but the two languages are not related.
Stack Overflow was launched in 2008 to provide a community-driven Q&A platform for programmers.
The world's first website, created by Tim Berners-Lee in 1991, is still online at http://info.cern.ch/
COBOL, a language still in use today, was created in 1959 for business applications.
The C programming language was developed at Bell Labs in the 1970s to help create the UNIX operating system.
PHP originally stood for 'Personal Home Page' but was later changed to 'PHP: Hypertext Preprocessor.'
You can write a full program in Brainfuck with only eight characters: `><+-.,[]`.
The space shuttle used computers with only 1MB of RAM during its missions.
The world's first computer virus, 'Creeper,' was created in the early 1970s and displayed the message: 'I’m the Creeper, catch me if you can!'
The popular Python framework Django is named after Django Reinhardt, a jazz guitarist.
Dennis Ritchie, co-creator of Unix and the C language, received far less public recognition than Steve Jobs or Bill Gates.
Facebook was originally built using PHP and later rewritten in Hack, a language developed by Facebook.
The Linux kernel is mostly written in C, with a small percentage written in assembly language.
Morse code inspired the binary numbering system used in computers today.
The 'QWERTY' keyboard layout was designed in the 1870s for typewriters and is still in use today despite alternatives like Dvorak and Colemak.
Over 90% of the world's supercomputers run on Linux.
The Java mascot is called 'Duke' and was originally designed as an animated character for interactive TV applications.
The 'Foo' and 'Bar' used in programming examples come from the military slang term 'FUBAR' (F***ed Up Beyond All Recognition).
